overview: When you reach State Pension age you stop paying National Insurance and can get extra tax-free allowances to reduce your Income Tax - filling in your Pension Coding form, tax if you carry on working, claiming back overpaid tax
title: Tax and National Insurance after State Pension age

table.body:
When you reach [State Pension age](http://pensions-service.direct.gov.uk/en/state-pension-age-calculator/home.asp "State Pension age"){:rel="external"} you stop paying National Insurance. 

You only pay Income Tax if your taxable income - including your pension - is more than your [tax-free allowances](/income-tax-rates "tax-free allowances") (the amount of income you're allowed before you pay tax).

##Should you be paying tax?

HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) should send you a Pension Coding form to help work out if you should be paying tax and how much. You should get this before you reach State Pension age.

If you're within a month of reaching State Pension age and you haven't been sent a form, [contact HMRC](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?sr=0&as=1&cs=ISO-8859-1&sc=hmrc&sf=&sm=0&nh=50&ha=34&tx0=49612&fl0=__dsid:&tx1=2037&raction=view "contact HMRC"){:rel="external"}.

Or you can download one below:

$D

[Download 'Form P161 Pension Coding form' (PDF, 62KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/p161-man.pdf "Download 'Form P161 Pension Coding form' (PDF, 62KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

^You won't automatically get a Pension Coding form if you're self-employed.^


*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
If you don't return your Pension Coding form you might end up paying too much tax.

##Filling in the form

You'll need to tell HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC):

- whether you've decided to claim your State Pension now or later
- the date you expect payments to start 
- the expected weekly amount you'll get

You'll also have to give details of:

- other pensions you get
- any income from [Jobseeker's Allowance](/jobseekers-allowance "Jobseeker's Allowance"), [Incapacity Benefit](/incapacity-benefit "Incapacity Benefit") or [Employment and Support Allowance](/employment-support-allowance "Employment and Support Allowance")
- income from employment if you're still employed
- savings income
- details of any charity donations you've made using Gift Aid

^You only need to include taxable income on the form - there's a list of [taxable and non-taxable income](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/incometax/taxable-income.htm "taxable and non-taxable income"){:rel="external"} on the HMRC website.^

HMRC has put together a set of notes to help you fill out the form.

$D

[Download 'Pension coding form - help and guidance' (PDF, 55KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/p161-helpsheet.pdf "Download 'Pension coding form - help and guidance' (PDF, 55KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

##Sending off the form

If you got the form in the post, use the reply envelope to send it back. Otherwise send it to:

$A

HM Revenue & Customs  
Pay As You Earn  
PO Box 1970  
Liverpool  L75 1WX  

$A

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Filling in your Pension Coding form

table.body:
National Insurance contributions build up your entitlement to your State Pension. 

If you're employed you pay Class 1 National Insurance contributions as a percentage of your earnings. 

If you're self-employed you pay Class 2 contributions at a flat weekly rate and Class 4 contributions annually, as a percentage of your taxable profits.

##What happens at State Pension age

At [State Pension age](http://pensions-service.direct.gov.uk/en/state-pension-age-calculator/home.asp "State Pension age"){:rel="external"}:

- you stop paying Class 1 and Class 2 contributions, even if you're still working
- you still have to pay Class 4 contributions if you have taxable profits from the year you reach State Pension age - the next year, you'll be exempt

^If you continue working, you can get an Age Exemption Certificate to make sure you don't pay National Insurance - [contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?sr=0&as=1&cs=ISO-8859-1&sc=hmrc&sf=&sm=0&nh=50&ha=34&tx0=49620&fl0=__dsid:&tx1=2037&raction=view "contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)"){:rel="external"} to get one.^
table.title: Making sure you've stopped paying National Insurance

table.body:
If you keep working (or return to work) the tax you pay depends on your overall taxable income and the type of pension you're getting.

##If you're just getting the State Pension

You'll need to pay tax if your job, State Pension and any other income add up to more than your [tax-free allowance](/income-tax-rates "tax-free allowance").

If tax is due, HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) normally asks your employer to take it from your earnings - this is called PAYE (Pay As You Earn).

HMRC might ask you to fill in a [Self Assessment tax return](/file-your-self-assessment-tax-return "Self Assessment tax return") if your situation's complicated (eg if you've foreign income or a lot of investment income).  

##If you get more than one pension 

You'll have several [tax codes](/income-tax/tax-codes "tax codes") and payslips. You can [get your tax code corrected](/reporting-your-tax-code-as-wrong "get your tax code corrected") if you think it's wrong. 

##If you return to work after retirement

If you start a new job after retiring, your employer has to tell HMRC so they can get your tax right. 

If your total income is more than your tax-free allowance you'll have to pay tax. HMRC will give you a tax code and collect tax through PAYE.

^If you're earning a wage and getting a pension but you're still on a low income you can get [pension credit](/pension-credit "pension credit").^









*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
table.title: Tax if you carry on working and get a pension

table.body:
As you get older there are allowances that can reduce your tax.

##Increased Personal Allowance from age 65

If you get a Personal Allowance this increases in the tax year of your 65th birthday, depending on your taxable income - more information on the [allowance amounts](/income-tax-rates "allowance amounts") is online. 

##Married Couple's Allowance

You can claim this if you're married or in a civil partnership and at least one partner was born before 6 April 1935. It gets taken off your tax bill - the amount that's deducted depends on your income. 

You can find out more about [Married Couple's Allowance](/married-couples-allowance "Married Couple's Allowance") online.

##Maintenance Payments Relief

You can get an allowance to reduce your tax bill for maintenance payments you make to an ex-spouse or civil partner if:

- you or they were born before 6 April 1935
- you're separated or divorced and you're making payments under a court order
- the payments are for the maintenance of your ex-partner (as long as they haven't re-married or formed a new civil partnership) or your children under 21

###How much you can get

For the 2012-13 tax year Maintenance Payments Relief can reduce your tax bill by the lower of the following:

- £296 - where you make maintenance payments of £2,960 or more a year
- 10% of the money you've actually paid - where you make payments of less than £2,960 a year


###How to claim

You can claim Maintenance Payments Relief by [contacting HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/search.ladv?sr=0&as=1&cs=ISO-8859-1&sc=hmrc&sf=&sm=0&nh=50&ha=34&tx0=49612&fl0=__dsid:&tx1=2037&raction=view "contacting HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)"){:rel="external"}.

You can't claim a tax reduction for any voluntary payments you make.

^There's more information about [Income Tax rates and allowances](/income-tax-rates "Income Tax rates and allowances") online.^


*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Age-related tax allowances

table.body:
If you’ve overpaid tax or National Insurance you can claim it back. If you’re on a low income and have savings, you can claim back tax deducted from the savings interest before you received it.

##How to claim

You can [claim a tax refund](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/pensioners/claiming.htm "claim a tax refund"){:rel="external"} if you've:

- had too much deducted from your pension
- overpaid through your job
- overpaid National Insurance

If you complete a tax return, you can also correct mistakes and claim a refund via [Self Assessment](/file-your-self-assessment-tax-return "Self Assessment").

###Claiming back tax on savings interest

If you're on a low income (less than £155 a week) you can register to have savings interest paid tax-free. You can also claim a refund of any tax you've overpaid on interest.

If your taxable income is only slightly higher than your tax-free allowance you can pay tax at a rate of 10% instead of the usual 20%.

^You can check if you can [get your interest tax-free](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/calcs/r85/index.htm "get your interest tax-free"){:rel="external"} or [pay tax at the 10% rate](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/tdsi/ten-per-cent-guidance.htm "pay tax at the 10% rate"){:rel="external"} online.^
